awd_titl_txt: Systemic Transformation of Evidence-based Education Reform (STEER)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to transform the culture of STEM departments in research universities by balancing the values of research and teaching.  It accomplishes this by rewarding the adoption of evidence-based teaching strategies by faculty and graduate students.  The project helps these educators to adopt these practices through training programs, work assignments, and support structures.  The increase in student learning and retention will lead to improved rewards and prestige for faculty. The project also focuses on the special needs of under-represented groups and of students transferring from community colleges. The ultimate goal of transforming institutional culture is to increase the retention and preparation of STEM majors and to produce a greater number of STEM graduates who are well prepared for life, citizenship, and careers. The project is centered at the University of South Florida.  This University is partnering with Hillsborough Community College, which provides a large number of transfer students. Implementation will be guided by the extensive planning conducted over the past two years, supported in part by an NSF WIDER planning grant. This process resulted in the development of a systemic approach to creating a culture that balances research and teaching. 

The theory of change guiding this project is a combination of bottom-up and top-down strategies described in the research literature, notably the work of Adrianna Kezar.  This project will produce new research knowledge about deliberate institutional change in the form of validation, testing, and efficiency assessment of the underlying change strategies.  Six explicit change strategies are being implemented. These have been found to represent effective approaches to cultural change in research-intensive STEM departments.  A Transition Implementation Leadership Team (TILT) has been formed to lead these efforts. This team is broadly representative of faculty, administrators, and staff.  The change strategies include: partnering with a feeder community college to improve STEM student transfer and success; establishing interdisciplinary and departmental retreats that foster convergence in course design and adoption of evidence-based teaching; supporting faculty development; focusing initially on gateway courses then on other STEM courses; revising university policies to enhance the rewards for improved teaching; and training Graduate Teaching Assistants and student advisers.  The project will provide an analysis, interpretation, and synthesis of the results of its change efforts in formats understandable and useful for non-scientists in order to stimulate policy formulation by local, State and Federal agencies. A second knowledge goal is to develop understanding of the key elements driving change in a generalized context that is useful as an adaptable model for other colleges and universities  to guide their self-improvement efforts.

por.por_cntn:
STEER or Systemic Transformation of Education through Evidence based Reforms was a 5-year NSF-IUSE project (#1525574) with the goal of sustainably improving STEM teaching at the University of South Florida, (USF) and Hillsborough Community College, (HCC). The intellectual merit was to develop and document the improvement process so that it could be replicated at other institutions. The ultimate outcome would be improved student success in STEM (more degrees and more, diverse STEM graduates), powering an innovation economy.

Since improving faculty teaching is a complex and multidimensional process, a systems approach was purposely used, employing a host of different but complimentary approaches. The project leadership team was composed of diverse faculty and administrators who met biweekly to plan and evaluate progress. Each implementation was followed by replacements or refinements that led to increasingly positive results. An awareness building seminar series brought distinguished speakers from high profile universities and organizations to campus. Interdisciplinary retreats and disciplinary retreats which focused on the need for change, continued this process. These stimulated faculty from chemistry, biology and mathematics at the community college and university to align content and learning outcomes across introductory courses. Travel awards supported faculty in attending conference workshops on effective teaching practices in their disciplines and for those making presentations on their own teaching innovations. Highlighting and rewarding effective teaching, 4-6 faculty a year were competitively selected as “STEER Scholars”, functioning as exemplars and acting as a resource for other faculty. The Peer Teaching Observation Program and Course Modification Incentive Programs were perhaps the most effective in spreading change in the later years. In Peer Observation, teams of three faculty from different disciplines observe each other’s classrooms and meet to share their reflection on what they saw. STEER provides initial training on effective non-evaluative feedback, and introductions to a selection of teaching practices that are shown to be effective. This program helps faculty reflect on their own teaching and how it could be strengthened. Many participants went on to apply for course modification awards. These competitive awards provide stipends to faculty (or teams of faculty) who complete projects that introduce known more effective teaching practices in their classroom. Focused initially on large introductory courses the awards shifted to upper-level courses as improvements proceeded. STEER also provides resources and professional development for all new science teaching assistants. Three half-day workshops reflecting on effective teaching and inclusive teaching strategies were followed up with half-day workshops in fall and spring, capitalizing on the potential for TAs to improve STEM student success. 

Engagement from faculty and Instructional change continued to develop over the course of the project. At USF 47% (175/369) of College of Engineering and School of Natural Science and Mathematics faculty were engaged in at least one initiative (26% in multiple). Engagements spanned all levels of faculty rank, (52 professors, 40 associate professors, 20 assistant professors and 63 instructors). At HCC 46% (39/85) of Science and Math faculty participated.

Over 90% of introductory science and engineering courses now use more effective teaching strategies. Engineering has formalized a Peer Teaching Observation program and instituted a faculty conversation on teaching program. The USF Center for innovative Teaching and Learning has developed and expanded a Peer Observation program to all university faculty. The 38 STEER supported faculty travel awards led to 24 conference presentations on teaching innovations and STEER leadership has authored 25 presentations and publications on our approaches. Over 1000 transfer students were advised and supported in their transition from HCC to USF by 18 peer mentors. The teaching assistant professional development program engaged over 380 science graduate students in more effective teaching practices and the value of implementing inclusive classroom strategies. This program and the course modification program will continue supported by the Coalition for Science Literacy at the USF which shares leadership with STEER. Finally, over the project period the total number and percentage of STEM degrees in Engineering, Mathematics and the Sciences increased by 551 from 2,026, (34% of total degree) to 2,577 (38%), while degrees to underrepresented groups increased by 185, (total 796) increasing from 30 to 31% of STEM degrees in our target areas. These increases were major goals of STEER.

Important lessons learned:

  • Resources are essential for success (incentives work!) 
  • Knowledgeable, dedicated, and diverse leadership is necessary (provides more and better ideas and reaches and influences different constituencies)
  • Leadership should meet regularly and follow a process of plan, do, reflect, and modify to have success.
  • Flexibility and a willingness to harness serendipity improves outcomes
  • Leadership should have influence among faculty as well as among administrators
  • Regularly recognize, respect and reward faculty success in teaching improvements
  • Building a brand of support for teaching innovation increases faculty involvement in new initiatives
  • Leadership must be patiently impatient since culture changes takes time
